awd_titl_txt: CRII: CHS: Healthcare Professionals Teaching Robots Communication Strategies for Effective Intervention Delivery
awd_abstract_narration:
There is a persistent shortage of healthcare workers in the USA. Occupations such as behavioral therapists, nurses, physical therapists, and home care workers are among the most in demand present and future healthcare professions. Socially assistive robots are a new strategic technology that has the potential to alleviate labor concerns in the healthcare industry by amplifying the capabilities of our existing labor force in delivering healthcare interventions to individuals in need. However, these robotic technologies remain difficult to scale and challenging to integrate in real-world healthcare intervention delivery due to the rapidly changing needs of healthcare service consumers that often require adaptation of existing interventions or development of new interventions. This project will build enabling technologies for healthcare professionals to generate and customize robot-mediated interventions according to the needs of their consumers as well as their clinical settings. The developed technology will also enable healthcare professionals to teach robots communication strategies for effective intervention delivery so that socially assistive robots can provide on par intervention services as their human teachers. Hence, this work will benefit society by alleviating the existing labor concerns for the healthcare industry and make healthcare services more accessible as well as customizable to consumers via collaboration with socially assistive robots. The outcomes of this research will advance knowledge in effective human-robot communication, robot learning, and human-robot teaching interfaces.

To address these goals, this project will develop a Learning from Demonstration inspired framework that will enable healthcare professionals with no prior experience in programming to teach socially assistive robots to administer intervention and nonverbal communication strategies necessary for effective intervention delivery. The following fundamental research challenges will be addressed: 
(a)Teaching Interface: The researchers will design and build a socially immersive teaching interface which enables healthcare professionals to teleoperate a socially assistive robot to demonstrate intervention delivery tasks and effective nonverbal communication strategies during the intervention. The primary focus will be identifying teleoperation modalities that are most effective and efficient for attaining high-quality demonstrations from healthcare professionals. 
(b) Learning Interventions from Demonstrations: Algorithms will be designed to learn from demonstrations by healthcare professionals’ models of the structure of an intervention delivery task, effective nonverbal communication behaviors they use during these interventions, and the context of their use. These learned models will then be utilized by a socially assistive robot to carry out the learned interventions for healthcare service consumers.
(c) Nonverbal Communication during Interventions: The project will culminate in a human-robot interaction study focusing on integrating and evaluating robot-mediated interventions, which utilize human-like nonverbal communication strategies, in real-world intervention delivery scenarios.
The outcomes of this research will advance knowledge in effective human-robot communication, robot learning, and human-robot teaching interfaces.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Healthcare occupations such as behavior therapists, nurses, physical therapists, and home care workers are among the most in demand professions due to an aging population, but the current supply of workers cannot keep up with present or future healthcare demands. Consequently, there is an urgent need to investigate methodologies to support current and future demands of the healthcare service sector.

The last two decades of socially assistive robot (SAR) research has focused on the development of autonomous social robots and have shown great promise in aiding to address workforce needs for healthcare providers. SARs aid humans through social interaction and have been validated with multiple target populations from children with autism to older adults with dementia. These robots have been utilized for tasks such as facilitating recreational activities, therapeutic play interventions, coaching/instruction during an activity, and providing companionship. In these applications, robots have been effective for engaging users in physically, cognitively, and socially stimulating interventions with positive behavioral, health, and educational outcomes. However, current SARs are limited to the set of interventions and communication strategies that have been pre-programmed on the robot by a roboticist and don?t address the diverse set of needs of healthcare service recipients.

More recently, significant robotics research progress has been made towards enabling individuals without programming knowledge to teach robots new social interaction tasks such as serving as a shopkeeper in a camera store, social companion to a child during educational games, tutor during collaborative video games with high school students, behavior therapist for interventions with children with autism, or facilitating group recreational activities with older adults. However, these systems currently focus on ?what? content is should delivered to a healthcare recipient but neglect ?how? the healthcare content should be communicated to an individual to be effective. Communication strategies are important because they contribute to positive healthcare outcomes in all health settings such as recreational therapy for older adults in residential care facilities, social skills training for children with autism, physical therapy, physical exercise programs, or preventative health interventions.  

This project focused on building a system whereby healthcare professionals can teach a robot a healthcare delivery task and nonverbal communication strategies necessary to provide care to a patient or client. As interpersonal communication is often an automatic process that humans find difficult to describe explicitly, we focused on developing methods that enable healthcare professionals to teach a robot simply by naturally demonstrating the appropriate behaviors and task to it.

Our work has led to the successful development of a novel system that enables individuals with limited programming knowledge to teach a robot through demonstration healthcare interventions and nonverbal communication strategies. The system has been utilized to teach robots the delivery of applied behavior analysis-based therapies for individuals with autism and nonverbal communication strategies such as appropriate turn-taking, backchanneling, and prosody. This work also investigated the efficacy of robot-mediated autism interventions that were developed alongside healthcare professionals. The robot-mediated autism interventions include group interaction skill training for children, interview training for adults, intraverbal skills training for children, and listening comprehension skills training for children.

This project has led to significant workforce development in computer science and healthcare by training a new generation of students. In computer science, this includes training of two PhD students, three master?s students, and twelve undergraduates. All these students have had the opportunity to participate in a multi-disciplinary research team with engineers, computer scientists, healthcare professionals, and educators. In healthcare, we held workshops with therapists in training to provide education on how to use robots for therapies.

Over twenty individuals also received robot-mediated therapy through these research activities. All these individuals acquired valuable skills and improved upon their conditions from the robot interventions.
